H0.text: A nucleus is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

H1.text: A molecule is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

H2.text: An element is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

H3.text: An atom is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that still has the properties of that compound.

A4.text: However, the majority of familiar solid substances on Earth are made partly or completely of crystals or ionic compounds, which are not made of molecules.

A5.text: A molecule is a group of two or more atoms that are held together by attractive forces known as chemical bonds.

A6.text: A molecule is the smallest unit of a substance that still carries all the physical and chemical properties of that substance.

A7.text: A molecule consisting of atoms of only one element is therefore not a compound.

A8.text: Atoms are the basic particles of the chemical elements and the fundamental building blocks of matter.

A9.text: A chemical element is a species of atom defined by its number of protons.

A10.text: Chemical compounds are substances made of atoms of different elements.
